reviewText:
The Collider places you inside of a particle accelerator that shoots you to incredibly fast speeds. The object of the game is to get as far along as you can before crashing. As you move along at dizzying speeds, you collect coins while avoiding obstacles. The coins can be used to revive you when you crash (which will be very often) up to three times in a round, which ends up being very helpful once you get farther along in the accelerator. There is a nice variety of obstacles, but I sometimes wish there were more.

The sound is okay, but not something I would want to listen to for long. Luckily, there is a mute button, so this isn't a problem. You can just rock out to whatever you want, while improving your reflex skills.

There's not much to The Collider, but it's definitely worth picking up if you like racing games. It's also nice for achievement hunters, since it only take a little bit of time to unlock them all. Be sure to get it while it's on sale, for that's when you'll be happiest with your purchase.

reviewText:
The Collider is an exhilerating Indie title in which you navigate through a tunnel at an increasing speed while trying to make it through the same type of obstacle -- the infamous rotating vertical disc with a hole in it. Spooky.

If you played Rayman 3: Hoodlum Havoc and partook in the Missile Command minigame, this should feel familiar to you. You're essentially guiding a camera through a series of conveniently placed rotating discs with holes in them. The holes differ in size and shape, which I find to be challenging yet rewarding. As time progresses, the speed at which you're zooming by increases exponentially with each interval (every time the counter reaches 100, to be exact). If you're appreciative of pretty colors, you're in for quite the treat here -- there are a lot of them.

The soundtrack in the game is an upbeat electronic motivator. It makes the entire experience a bit more exciting, though it does get old as you continue playing. Hearing the same song over and over again typically doesn't bode well if it doesn't resonate with its listener, surprisingly enough. Still, though -- it's a tune I certainly wanted to dance to at one point.

If you're looking for a euphoric graphical experience, you've come to the wrong place. You can see for yourself in the screenshots provided on the game's store page.

The only indication that you're finished with the game would have to be the achievements. I'm not too keen on my champion status (the game includes a leaderboard), and as such, the game is finished for me once I've acquired all of the achievements available for me to earn.

The only issue I've found within the game is that at a certain point, your crosshair is simply too large. I often found myself struggling to see where the hole was because of it. It's easily remedied by proper peripheral vision, though.

reviewText:
The Collider is an odd reflex game. It's along the same lines as Super Hexagon in that it's addictive and high-energy, but is basically a flash game.

The objective here is to guide a small dot in the center of your monitor through an infinitely long tube comprised of screens with holes in it; you hit a screen, you die. The ultimate goal is to survive as long as possible. If you can guess, the game is rather punishing: expect to die a lot and make very little progress.

The achievements are very wonky and unlock all at once after you quit the game. It took me all of 19 minutes of gameplay to get them all without trying--so there's that.

In conclusion, other than demanding intense focus and quick reflexes, this game doesn't offer a lot of playtime. There are no special modes or items--just the base game. It's interesting the first few times around, but definitely not worth $3. Maybe try it if it's on sale and you have an extra quarter lying around, but otherwise, skip it.

Bought this game because I had a 90% off coupon, if you don't have this coupon do not buy this game.  It is not worth paying more than 10% of the price for this game.

1/2 an hour later I completed the entire game with unlocking all of the speeds and getting all of the achievements except because this is such a wonderful game the achievements don't even unlock.

Anyhow, it's pretty basic mindless ♥♥♥♥, I like to turn stuff like this on before playing fps games as it gets you in the habit of flicking your mouse at high speeds as things are rapidly approaching.  All in all, it's worth the 30 cents I paid for it, but not worth 2.99.

Let me say this straight and simple: If you are going to buy this game, you are going to buy this game because of the incredible ease it takes to obtain all the achievements. It takes most about 20-60 minutes to do this, and even still many people have difficulty getting the achievements validated. Look to the forums if you have problems, the solutions are there.

The reason why I put this as thumbs down is because there is a free (and much better) game that is like this one on Kongregate. It is called Accelerator, here's the link http://www.kongregate.com/games/TenebrousP/accelerator.

The main differences between this one that you are paying money for and the free one are the sounds, visual, and a few game play differences. Accelerator has a much better sound system, but no music. It doesn't need it. It ends up giving a much better atmosphere than Collider without the music. Also complimenting the atmosphere are the visuals. There are no drastic colour changes besides the square tunnels being blue. This gives the game a more stream lined sense, and helps the progression without accidentally crashing.

While this isn't a problem in Collider because of the reviving function, Accelerator doesn't have that. it is much more harder because of this and you feel like you have actually achieved something. What Accelerator does have is a difficulty setting, and this changes one thing mainly, the level design. Harder difficulty levels will result in tight corners and diverging paths, which when you are going fast, become really difficult to traverse. It just adds to the feel of satisfaction when you get that impossible badge for reaching a speed of 1000.

All in all, my basic gripe was paying for this. Yes it is cheap, yes it gave me a perfect achievement thing, but in all honesty, why play this when Accelerator on Kongregate is free and so much better?

To be frank, as said in many other reviews I read before even purchasing, it's really handy if you need to train your reaction skills for a FPS game (I play CS:GO and I do confirm I did improve a bit). Besides, it can help you waste some useless time, if you have any to spare.

However, the music is not that great, only 1 soundtrack looping over and over again. The most annoying thing is how fast things end, at least in my case. I spend less than a minute before having to start from the beginning (or alternatively start at a speed I reached before), which makes for even less time playing.

All in all, it's not bad for killing time, but you may get frustrated at how incompetent you are dodging obstacles at insanely increasing speeds.
Release Date: Sep 15, 2014???\n\nWe've come too far in gaming to be playing such a bland and unoriginal game.
8.5/10\nMay be a good choice for spending spare time, but not for people who can't make instant reactions.
